title: CSS Opacity
subject: CSS
theory:
The `opacity` property specifies the opacity/transparency of an element.

Values range from 0.0 (fully transparent/invisible) to 1.0 (fully opaque/solid).

**Note**: When using `opacity` on a parent element, all child elements also become transparent.

examples.output: Image becomes semi-transparent when mouse hovers over it.
examples.explanation: Effective for creating interactive UI elements.

common_mistakes.correction: If you set opacity on a div, the text inside fades too. Use `background-color: rgba()` if you only want the background transparent.
common_mistakes.example:
WRONG: .box { opacity: 0.5; } (Text fades)
CORRECT: .box { background: rgba(0,0,0,0.5); } (Text solid)

interview_questions.question: Difference between opacity: 0, visibility: hidden, and display: none?
interview_questions.answer: opacity: 0 - Element is there and takes space, clickable (usually). Visibility: hidden - Element takes space, not clickable. Display: none - Element gone.

real_world_use_cases.description: Disabled UI elements often have `opacity: 0.5` to visually indicate they are inactive.

exam_notes: Opacity is inherited by child elements.
Opacity does not affect layout flow.
summary: Opacity adds visual depth and interactivity feedback to elements.
